Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5PX8-HTJ1-JBSN-302J-00000-00News Briefs Nov. 8th, 20172017-11-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:01ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1News Briefs Nov. 8th, 2017

Eight killed in NYC terror attack

On Tuesday, Oct. 31, there was a terrorist attack in New York City. Just after 3 p.m., a rented Home Depot truck swerved into the Houston Street bike line along the West Side Highway, located in the lower part of Manhattan. The attack took place not far from the site of the Sept. 11 attacks. After striking multiple pedestrians and bikers, the driver crashed into a school bus near Chambers Street. Of those struck when the truck turned into the bike line, six were presumed dead at the scene and two more died at the hospital. Two children and two adults on the bus were wounded, but none of them fatally (New York Times, "Terror Attack Kills 8 and Injures 11 in Manhattan," 10.31.2017).

After the crash, the driver, Sayfullo Saipov, got out of the truck and ran through traffic, waving a paintball gun and a pellet gun. After yelling "Allahu Akbar," meaning "God is great" in Arabic, he was shot in the stomach by New York Police Department officer Ryan Nash on Chambers Street (CBS News, "'This Was An Act Of Terror': 8 Dead, More Than A Dozen Injured When Truck Strikes Pedestrians In Lower Manhattan," 10.31.2017).

The motorist is still alive, but is in police custody. The attack has been compared to the terrorist attack in Nice, France last year, in which a different motorist struck those celebrating Bastille Day.

Saipov, who is 29 years old, came to the United States from Uzbekistan in 2010. Prior to the attack, Saipov, a New Jersey resident, did not have a criminal history, and his only law violations were traffic-related. When he moved to the United States seven years ago, Saipov worked driving cars and trucks and recently begun driving for Uber, for which he passed the background check.

Law enforcement officials have concluded that Saipov was "self-radicalized" because he did not have ties to the terrorist organization, despite being inspired by it. This was further supported by findings of a note by the vehicle, reading "ISIS Lives Forever" in both English and Arabic. Saipov, who spent a year planning the motor attack, also requested that an ISIS flag be hung in his hospital room. On Thursday, Nov. 2, ISIS took credit for the attack that it had inspired (NBC News, "Sayfullo Saipov's Path from Immigrant Trucker to Suspected Terrorist," 11.01.2017).On Tuesday, Oct. 31, there was a terrorist attack in lower Manhattan, near the location of the Sept. 11 attacks. Eight people were killed and several more were injured. The perpetrator, Sayfullo Saipov, is alive and in custody, awaiting trial./ Courtesy of Pixabay

Normally, presidents of the United States are discourgaed from providing their opinons on unsettled criminal cases, as these thoughts can interfere with the trial. However, President Trump tweeted his response to the attack, stating that "In NYC, looks like another attack by a very sick and deranged person. Law enforcement is following this closely. NOT IN THE U.S.A.!" This was later followed up by another tweet reading, "He killed 8 people, badly injured 12. SHOULD GET DEATH PENALTY!" (New York Times, "Trump Declares Suspect 'Should Get Death Penalty,'" 11.01.2017).

-Pazit Schrecker, Guest Reporter

Mueller make first indictment charges

Ever since Trump's election, tremendous suspicion of Russia's involvement in the election is omnipresent in the news cycle, which eventually led to a federal investigation. This week, incriminating information about key figures from Trump's foreign policy sector of the campaign revealed potential collusion between Russia and the United States.

The first indictment charges were made under the investigation of special counsel Robert Mueller last week. The investigation is focusing on potential collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia that gave Trump his November victory. Those from Trump's campaign who were charged were scheduled to be taken into custody as soon as Monday. However, these charges were sealed from the public eye. Mueller's sealing of the documents sends a signal to other defendants that these are serious allegations worth decades of jail time (CNN, "First on CNN: First charges filed in Mueller investigation", 10.30.2017).

The indictments include Paul Manafort, Rick Gates and George Papadopoulos, all former Trump campaign aides. Manafort and Gates, who are longtime international business associates, were the first to be indicted on 12 counts, including conspiracy to launder money on behalf of the campaign. Gates and Manafort were both ousted from Trump's inner circle amidst rising suspicions about their lobbying work in Eastern Europe, especially in the Ukraine (Washington Post, "At least nine people in Trump's orbit had contact with Russians during campaign and transition," 11.5.2017).

According to their indictment, Manafort and Gates funneled millions of dollars to the United States from consulting a Ukrainian presidential campaign. The seemingly democratic candidate Victor Yanukovych had close ties to Vladimir Putin. Gates was found to have opened as many as 30 bank accounts this year alone-one with over $10 million dollars in Cyprus-which constitutes massive tax fraud (CBC News, "How cases of Paul Manafort and Sergei Magnitsky are linked: money laundering through Cyprus," 11.04.2017).

This week, it was discovered that Papadopoulos, a seemingly low level advisor to the campaign, was trying to set up meetings in Moscow with the Trump campaign. Evidence in Mueller's investigation suggests that Papadopoulos may have been directed by higher campaign members to spark collusion between the campaign and Russian authorities, including Vladimir Putin. It was later discovered that he sent emails to other campaign aides, notably Manafort and Gates, working on Trump's foreign policy about collaborating with Russia. In an email sent from Manafort to Gates, he wrote, "We need someone to communicate that DT is not doing these trips. It should be someone low level in the campaign so as not to send any signal" (NPR, "Former Trump Adviser Admits To Seeking 'Dirt' On Clinton From Russians, Lying To FBI," 10.30.2017).

Although he went to great lengths to skirt around Trump's national security, the 29-year-old Papadopoulos confessed to lying to the FBI about his relations with Russia. However, the exact question of the Trump campaign's alleged illegal collusion with Russia remain unanswered. Mueller's investigation suggests that the Russians had disclosed they had important, and perhaps incriminating, information about Hillary Clinton. These illegal meetings never happened, as the campaign claimed to have refused them.

The Trump administration tried to stop the investigation but ultimately failed. Furious after receiving notice about Mueller's strong prosecution advocating for electoral justice, Trump's tweet read, "This is the greatest witch hunt of a politician in American history!" (CNN, "Trump 'seething' as Mueller probe reaches former aides," 10.31.2017). In the upcoming weeks, the Mueller probe will continue to uncover the hidden truths behind Russia's role in the 2016 presidential election.

-Kelly Vinett, Guest Reporter

Congress holds hearings for tech giants

Last week marked the start of Congressional hearings for the biggest tech companies in the country in connection to their role in Russia's meddling in 2016 presidential election. On Tuesday, Oct. 31, and Wednesday, Nov. 1, three of the tech giants, Facebook, Twitter and Google, had to defend themselves in front of Senate in a series of three hearings over the two days. The hearings were conducted to investigate the role social media played in the 2016 presidential election and the extent of the reach and influence it had. It was the first time that tech companies testified in front of the Senate Judiciary Committee about the role they played in the elections. While the senators were hoping for a conversation with top executives, the corporations instead sent their in-house lawyers, putting themselves on the defensive.

At the beginning of this year, the U.S. Intelligence Community jointly confirmed Russian government interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election. One of the tactics was the use of social media to spread controversial and divisive messages, focusing on race, religion, gun rights and gay and transgender issues in the U.S. They used Facebook in two ways: firstly, by paying Facebook for advertisements and secondly, by creating Facebook groups where they promoted divisive messages and encouraged debate. The Russian government influenced the election by using Facebook's own strategy of encouraging people to be more engaged, by commenting, liking and sharing content. It has been revealed that a shadowy Russian company with links to the Kremlin, Internet Research Agency, posted around 80,000 pieces of divisive content that reached 19 million people between January 2015 and August 2017 (The Atlantic, "15 Things We Learned From the Tech Giants at the Senate Hearings," 10.02.2017). These posts were then shared, liked and commented on, spreading them to an even wider group of people. Moreover, Internet Research Agency paid Facebook more than $100,000 in advertisements (Reuters, "Facebook says 126 million Americans may have seen Russia-linked political posts," 10.30.2017).

Last week's hearings presented a shift in the relationship between Washington and Silicon Valley. For years their relationship has been very friendly, especially in regards to favorable regulatory treatment of Silicon Valley. However, the hearings revealed the increasing frustration with Silicon Valley in Washington. This was apparent in the line of questioning from Minnesota Senator Al Franken, who asked Facebook's general Counsel Colin Stretch: "You put billions of data points together all the time ... you can't put together rubles and a political ad? How did you not connect those two dots?" (Reuters, "U.S. senators hammer Facebook for power over elections," 10.31.2017). The past month has also seen a circulation of Senator Amy Klobuchar's bipartisan Honest Ads Bill, which would require political ads on the internet to be regulated in the same way as those on TV and radio (Business Insider, "McCain, Democrats introduce first major legislation targeting Facebook ads since Russia intervened in the 2016 elections," 10.19.2017). Facebook has taken some steps to change its practices when it comes to political ads in order to avoid regulation from Washington and has hired 1,000 new people to review political ads. The argument for self-regulation has been present in the discourses of all the big tech companies.

-Marusa Rus, Guest Reporter

ISIS loses control of Deir al-Zour

Last Friday, the Islamic State suffered an important defeat by Syrian government forces, Iraqi militaries and international backers of both armies and lost much of its territory.

Syrian forces declared victory in Deir al-Zour, the last major city held by ISIS. The city is regarded as an important place geographically and economically; it is near the Iraqi border and has abundant amount of oil. As a result, the Syrian government and ISIS had an ongoing territorial dispute over the city. Deir al-Zour has been divided into a Syrian portion and an ISIS portion for three years (Independent, "ISIS Driven Out of Final City Stronghold in Syria," 11.03.2017).

However, allied with Russian and Iranian army, Syrian forces started to besiege Deir al- Zour against ISIS and have been moving forward ever since. Finally, last Friday, they succeeded in recovering control over the city (Independent, "ISIS Driven Out of Final City Stronghold in Syria," 11.03.2017).

"The armed forces, in cooperation with allied forces, liberated the city of Deir al-Zour completely from the clutches of the Daesh terrorist organization," Syrian state media reported, using an Arabic acronym for ISIS (Reuters, "Islamic State on Verge of Defeat After Fresh Losses in Syria, Iraq," 11.03.2017).

Meanwhile, on the opposite side of the border, the Iraqi military allied with Iranian army took over al-Qaim, the border-crossing city near the Euphrates River. Iraq's Prime Minister Haidar Abadi announced that government forces succeeded in seizing power over the city (Independent, "ISIS Driven Out of Final City Stronghold in Syria," 11.03.2017).

After these defeats, ISIS is now isolated in the small desert countryside surrounded by its opponents. Indeed, it has lost 90 percent of its territory in the last three years, including key cities such as Mosul in Iraq and Raqqa in Syria (Reuters, "Islamic State on Verge of Defeat After Fresh Losses in Syria, Iraq," 11.03.2017).

Syrian forces against ISIS anticipated that a few more wars are left in order to annihilate ISIS influence on territories. They estimated that ISIS does not have many soldiers left; around 1,500 to 2,500 soldiers are estimated to remain in al-Qa'im and 2,000 to 3,000 in Abu Kamal (Independent, "ISIS Driven Out of Final City Stronghold in Syria," 11.03.2017).

Refugees from Deir al-Zour and al-Qa'im were also relieved by the victory. Hosna Quray'a, a refugee from Deir al-Zour who has stayed at a school shelter in Qudsaya, commented to The New York Times, "I want to return. Most of my relatives left there, and I don't know what happened to them" (The New York Times, "ISIS, Squeezed on Two Sides, Loses Syrian City and Border Crossing," 11.03.2017).

However, there are several obstacles to the fully recover the lost territory and to wipe out ISIS's power. To begin with, the war is not finished yet. Both the Iraqi and Syrian government are cautious about guerrilla attacks of ISIS (Independent, "ISIS Driven Out of Final City Stronghold in Syria," 11.03.2017).

Moreover, for the refugees, the victory does not mean they can immediately return to their homes. The cities may still contain numerous land mines and ISIS sleeper cells. It will also take a huge amount of time to rebuild the destroyed cities again (The New York Times, "ISIS, Squeezed on Two Sides, Loses Syrian City and Border Crossing," 11.03.2017).

Finally, the political conflicts among the militaries would be a critical concern in the aftermath of the war. The New York Times reported, "That battle for the remaining Islamic State territory could inflame tensions among the competing forces fighting the militants as they converge on the region ... the competing armies [are] seeking not only to vanquish the Islamic State, but [are] also racing against each other to win influence in the strategic border zone" (The New York Times, "ISIS, Squeezed on Two Sides, Loses Syrian City and Border Crossing," 11.03.2017).

- Youngju Chang, Guest Reporter

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WK9-KD01-DY1J-T379-00000-00News Brief: Trump Tweets, Asylum Rule, Big Tech Hearings2019-07-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:01ZLexisNexisMorning Edition09:00 PM ESTDomenico MontanaroJames FredrickAarti ShahaniNoel KingSteve InskeepIlhan OmarAyanna PressleySteven MnuchinNews Brief: Trump Tweets, Asylum Rule, Big Tech Hearings

STEVE INSKEEP: How do four Americans respond to the president suggesting they leave?

NOEL KING: All four of them are members of the House of Representatives. They are Democrats Rashida Tlaib, Ayanna Pressley, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Ilhan Omar. Omar yesterday pointed out that the president, who complained about their complaining, is noted for his loud and frequent complaining.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

ILHAN OMAR: For him to condemn us and to say we are un-American for wanting to work hard to make this country be the country we all deserve to live in - complete hypocrisy.

NOEL KING: She was responding to President Trump saying that these women of color should, quote, "go back to where they came from."

STEVE INSKEEP: Mostly, they were born in the United States. Now, how is the president explaining himself? NPR lead political editor Domenico Montanaro is with us once again. Domenico, good morning.

DOMENICO MONTANARO: Good morning, Steve.

STEVE INSKEEP: OK, so he begins by saying these people mostly born in the U.S. should go back. They're people who are from here but just of a different race than him. And then he came out and made a statement - the president did - saying, well, what I meant was if you don't like America, you can leave. But isn't he pretty much saying the same thing?

DOMENICO MONTANARO: Right. I mean, the president showed no contrition, essentially, for racist remarks. He instead - he emphasized them. He said, if you hate our country, if you're not happy here, you can leave. Now, the rhetoric has gone too far for many Republicans. They're voicing disapproval of the president's remarks. They're also criticizing the congresswomen, though, calling them socialists or far-left or, quote, "anti-Semitic" - using anti-Semitic rhetoric.

Most of them, though, stopped short of calling the tweets racist. You heard from Will Hurd of Texas, who is black, who called Trump's tweets racist, as did Mike Turner of Ohio. But others like Pat Toomey of Pennsylvania, Susan Collins of Maine, Mitt Romney of Utah - they called the remarks, you know, destructive, demeaning, disunifying and, also, over the line, which I guess, Steve, means there is a line.

STEVE INSKEEP: Oh. Well, interesting to learn that. Why would the president go over that line, then?

DOMENICO MONTANARO: You know, the fact is the president and the Republican Party want to elevate these four congresswomen to make them the, quote, "face of the Democratic Party" - you heard Lindsey Graham say that on Fox News yesterday, for example. You know, they think that that is something that helps them because it makes the Democratic Party look far-left. Ayanna Pressley argued that the congresswomen's views are not total outliers.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

AYANNA PRESSLEY: Our squad is big. Our squad includes any person committed to building a more equitable and just world. And that is the work that we want to get back to.

STEVE INSKEEP: I guess we should define some terms there. They've been called the squad, these four freshmen members of Congress. And when she says, our squad is big, she's referring to - she's asserting that, actually, they have a lot of support; they're not just four freshmen.

DOMENICO MONTANARO: Right. And the fact, though, is that within the Democratic conference, they've had some disagreement with leadership, with Nancy Pelosi, whether it's tactically or ideologically. But for now, I have to say, this helps Nancy Pelosi. It's a pretty big gift to her to maintain unity because, instead of the focus being on that Democratic infighting, it's on Trump. And Pelosi is now calling on Congress to condemn Trump's remarks and wants to put Republicans on record.

STEVE INSKEEP: Although, the way that Republicans will spin this is, look - all the Democrats have now been glued to these four lawmakers that we want to describe as socialist and so forth. So what does this mean for the 2020 election?

DOMENICO MONTANARO: Well, they'll certainly attempt that. But this whole incident's a reminder that identity politics are going to be, unavoidably, a top issue for 2020. Republicans and the Trump campaign are happy to have it that way. They think it helps them. They think it throws the left off balance.

But stepping back, Steve, the fabric of the country is really being stretched. I mean, you have demographic change in this country that's upsetting half the country, while the other half is painting in primary colors, emboldened. They feel under siege by Trump. And, you know, it's unclear what it's going to mean for 2020 at the ballot box next year, and it's even cloudier for our culture and what it means to be American.

STEVE INSKEEP: One of the questions, of course, will be who gets the half or a little more than half or a little less than half? Domenico, thanks so much.

DOMENICO MONTANARO: You're so welcome.

STEVE INSKEEP: That's Domenico Montanaro. Now, amid all the attention on the president's racist language, his administration continued its push to reshape immigration policy.

NOEL KING: Yeah, that's right. Yesterday, the Trump administration announced a new rule for migrants from Central America who want to get asylum in the U.S. They first have to apply for asylum in a country that they traveled through on their way to the United States, and if they're rejected by one of those countries, only then can they seek asylum here. Now, that rule is scheduled to go into effect today, and it will certainly face challenges in court.

STEVE INSKEEP: Reporter James Fredrick is in Mexico City and covering this story. Hey. Good morning

JAMES FREDRICK: Morning, Steve.

STEVE INSKEEP: So I'm trying to figure this out - if you show up at the U.S.-Mexico border and say, I'm seeking asylum, is the asylum officer, the federal agent there, going to say, OK, prove to me you tried in Guatemala first?

JAMES FREDRICK: Exactly. I mean, what this establishes is that, if you show up at the U.S. border now to request asylum, basically, you're not - ineligible unless you can prove you've tried to apply elsewhere and have been rejected. So, I mean, this applies to everyone who's coming to the southern border. The administration says that this policy is to crack down on what it calls fraudulent asylum claims. But the result is that someone who could have been granted asylum yesterday had they been able to apply, well, today that same person can't even apply and could be deported to their home country.

In terms of who this affects, we're talking mostly people from Central America. But it's not just them; it's anyone who's come through Mexico. I've met people from as far as Venezuela, the Congo, Ukraine who have come through here to apply for asylum. It would affect all of them. And the question now is how - what this looks like on the ground. One question is what do they do with people who break this rule now? Will they deport them to their home country, to a place where they say they're not safe? That's a big question right now.

STEVE INSKEEP: Now, I want to think this through. First, we should note - this is kind of normal, that you encourage people to just go one country over and stay near where they came from. I mean, refugees from Afghanistan end up in Pakistan or Iran, for example. So it's not that unusual to have the impulse to say, if you're fleeing El Salvador, maybe you should go to Guatemala, maybe you should just go to Mexico, you should go somewhere nearby. But that does raise a question - can people get asylum? Can people be safe in Guatemala or Mexico?

JAMES FREDRICK: In theory, yes. In practice, in a place like Guatemala - Guatemala officially does allow asylum-seekers, but it doesn't have an office to even process that. So, I mean, the capacity for it just doesn't exist right now. In Mexico, it's a bit different; Mexico does process tens of thousands of asylum requests a year. The problem right now is that Mexico's asylum office has an annual budget of $1.2 million. They've already had 30,000 asylum requests this year. They just have nowhere near the funds to resettle more people or even the number of people who are requesting asylum right now. So practically, it just doesn't seem feasible in other countries like that.

STEVE INSKEEP: Have Mexican officials indicated they're going to try to deal with this?

JAMES FREDRICK: They have not said anything. They mostly said that this is a domestic policy in the U.S., so they can't challenge it. But what they're going to do is a big question because this would be a huge burden on them to take tens of thousands of more people, possibly.

STEVE INSKEEP: Reporter James Fredrick, in Mexico City. Thanks, as always.

JAMES FREDRICK: Thanks, Steve.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

STEVE INSKEEP: OK, wow - three congressional hearings today in Washington, three of them, put the power struggle between Congress and big tech on display.

NOEL KING: And when we talk about big tech, we're talking about a handful of companies - Facebook, Amazon, Google and Apple. Some members of Congress are concerned about the influence that these companies have over billions of people's lives. And today, lawmakers get to question executives from those companies.

STEVE INSKEEP: NPR's Aarti Shahani will be listening and is on the line. Good morning.

AARTI SHAHANI: Good morning.

STEVE INSKEEP: OK, let's start with Facebook, which is the sole focus of a hearing before the Senate Banking Committee. Why banking?

AARTI SHAHANI: That's right. So you may have heard Facebook plans to create its own money called the Libra. The stated goal is to bank the unbanked. An estimated 1.7 billion adult on Earth do not have a bank account; many of them are Facebook users. So Facebook is going to create its own currency, taking on a key power of nation-states - the power to mint money. But Facebook has got to clear a lot of hurdles. What are they and their partners going to do about money laundering? How will they protect privacy? What happens to the interest earned on Libra deposits?

Regulators are speaking up about it and striking very different tones. France's finance minister came out saying Facebook shouldn't have a sovereign currency. The U.K. minister says his country is willing to engage with Facebook. And U.S. Treasury Secretary Stephen Mnuchin made it clear in a briefing yesterday that he is not comfortable with Facebook launching a currency, at least not yet.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

STEVEN MNUCHIN: I think they're being very candid with the administration in where they are. I'm not going to publicly speculate how long I think it will take them to get to the point where we're comfortable with it. But they are a long way away.

STEVE INSKEEP: Facebook by now, of course, has heard some of the criticism. How are they responding?

AARTI SHAHANI: So the company is sending David Marcus. He's heading the creation of this Libra wallet. He used to head PayPal. His testimony, which he submitted, it's very diplomatic. He's going to say Facebook will not launch Libra until his team has fully addressed regulatory concerns and received appropriate approvals. So, you know, it seems like, at least today, Facebook is talking the talk.

STEVE INSKEEP: And we'll find out how the walk goes a little bit later.

AARTI SHAHANI: (Laughter) That's right. That's right.

STEVE INSKEEP: In the House, some lawmakers are asking if some of these companies amount to monopolies.

AARTI SHAHANI: That is correct, and there is an entire hearing today that's really dedicated to how these platforms work. The House Judiciary Committee members are going to drill into Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple - how they deal with competitors and collaborators.

And, you know, Steve, here's the thing - is that these companies do have differences. For example, Amazon and Google both collect advertising money. But Amazon's ad money is basically a fee to vendors for them to show up in Amazon's search pages; Google is not that. As one person close to the companies pointed out to me, it is in each of their interests to not point fingers at each other, to not throw each other under the bus. They'll want to stick together and make the antitrust conversation go away.

STEVE INSKEEP: Kind of act like, I don't know, a big tech monopoly or something like that.

AARTI SHAHANI: (Laughter) Well, and coordinated - coordinated, correct.

STEVE INSKEEP: (Laughter) Coordinated messaging - that's something different, I know, I know, I know.

AARTI SHAHANI: Yes.

STEVE INSKEEP: Third hearing is about what actually gets carried on social media and what allegedly gets blocked.

AARTI SHAHANI: That's right. That's right. Senator Ted Cruz, he has long criticized social media platforms for anti-conservative bias. Today, he's going to grill a Google lobbyist, specifically, on whether the company is tweaking its algorithms, manipulating search to suppress certain ideologies. So, again, does big tech have too much power?

STEVE INSKEEP: Can't wait for people to be googling the results of that hearing to see whether it comes up.

AARTI SHAHANI: (Laughter).

STEVE INSKEEP: Aarti, thanks so much.

AARTI SHAHANI: Thank you.

STEVE INSKEEP: That's NPR's Aarti Shahani.

(SOUNDBITE OF STAN FOREBEE'S "REFLECTIONS")

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XR6-KNH1-DXH2-6046-00000-00News Corp at UBS Global TMT Conference - Final2019-12-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:01ZLexisNexis121019a12933308.708News Corp at UBS Global TMT Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Michael Florin

News Corporation - Senior VP & Head of IR

Conference Call Participants

* Harold Vogel;Vogel Capital Inc.;Analyst

* Thomas G. Beadle

UBS Investment Bank, Research Division - Associate Director and Research Analyst

Presentation

THOMAS G. BEADLE, ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR AND RESEARCH ANALYST, UBS INVESTMENT BANK, RESEARCH DIVISION: Okay. We might get started. Good morning, and thanks for joining us, everyone. My name is Tom Beadle. I cover the Australian TMT space. And as part of that, I'm the lead analyst for News Corporation.

So it's my pleasure this morning to introduce you to Mike Florin, Senior Vice President and Head of Investor Relations at News Corp.

Just as a reminder, before we get started, we do have the conference app here, please feel free to enter questions into the app. We're also going to go a bit old school here. We'll have a mic around -- floating around the room, so we'll be taking questions from the floor as well. So...

MICHAEL FLORIN, SENIOR VP & HEAD OF IR, NEWS CORPORATION: Good to be here.

Questions and Answers

THOMAS G. BEADLE: So I guess, just maybe a high-level question first. The key strategic priority for News Corp seems to have shifted to simplifying the structure recently. So can you talk about some of the initiatives and maybe an update on NAM and Unruly and just maybe talk about some of the other key priorities of the News Corp over the next 1 to 3 years?

MICHAEL FLORIN: Okay. Well -- good question, Tom. So let's start with just the high level because I do think, kind of looking at where we come from is very important to maybe where we're going. And when I joined the company, when we separated from the old News Corp, I mean we were a company that was -- almost 3/4 of revenues were in newspapers and -- News and Information Services. The vast majority of our EBITDA was in News and Information Services, and the nickname that we were given was PubCo.

And when you look at how the business has changed, we were -- we tripled our exposure to digital real estate. That's become a very big part of our revenue and EBITDA. We've expanded HarperCollins. We exited Digital Education. So the business has changed. Advertising, which used to be 49% of our revenues was, I think less than 1/3. The subscription and circulation, what I call the recurring subscription base has come from, I don't know, I think it was 25% at the time we separated and now it's our biggest revenue stream. So the business has transformed far differently than people expected. And today, we have a business that has a very good balance between News and Information Services, Digital Real Estate, the Book Publishing business and obviously, real estate.

So going back to your question, I'd say, so the priorities for us. When I look at our segments, what are we trying to accomplish? One, in News and Information Services, it really is about becoming much more digital, streamline the cost base, big focus on Dow Jones. At digital real estate, it really is about expanding into adjacencies, growing our audiences. And I think we've done a very good job on that. At Foxtel, we get to a lot of questions on and you'll probably ask a question later, but on Foxtel, it really is about IP, pushing IP more aggressively. And in Book Publishing, it's a lot of blocking and tackling. And when I think about that business, that really is a content business. It's not a book business -- it's not just a book business, it really is about content.

Now on your question on simplification. The way I think about it, with everything we do, there's always a review of our asset base. And looking at the portfolio and what are the best levers to drive growth and value. When it comes down to something like News America Marketing or in whatever -- any of our businesses, I kind of break it down into 3 questions that you got to answer. One, is it an area that you want to reinvest in? And what kind of return will you get on it? Two, does it cloud the value or detract the value of the segment? So in this case, Dow Jones. I mean Dow Jones is a really, really important asset for us. And one that, candidly, I think, is worth a lot more than The Street might think. And so how do we better highlight that to some extent? And then the last part is, are there broader synergies? Or how great are the synergies across the rest of the portfolio?

So with News America Marketing and Unruly, we have both -- both are under sort of strategic review, and we'll update the market when something's finalized. But it clearly is a big focus and one that if I think about News and Information Services, today, that segment is pretty balanced now between revenues and circulation. If you were to exclude News America Marketing, as an example, all of a sudden, a vast majority of the revenues become subscription and circulation, really starts to change the revenue exposure of that business. And I think it gives a heck a lot more transparency into the business. And -- but again, a big part of the focus is how do we best highlight Dow Jones.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: Yes. And I guess, maybe on that point, so the business has returned. Dow Jones has returned to low single-digit growth over the past couple of years. So maybe if you could talk about what's driving this and what initiatives you're undertaking to grow revenue further. And maybe just as a comp -- compare yourselves to maybe your competitor like a New York Times for example?

MICHAEL FLORIN: Yes. That's a great question. So when I think about -- like last quarter, we'll take the first quarter, our fiscal first quarter. Our revenue growth at Dow Jones was 6%. That's a really good number. When you think about how -- what the drivers are that -- the biggest revenue bucket at Dow Jones is consumer circulation. Consumer circulation revenues grew 6%. We had, I think it was, 17% growth in digital-only subscribers at Dow Jones. The Wall Street Journal total subscriber growth grew 8%. Those are really good numbers inside the consumer side of the business.

For us, advertising grew modestly, grew 2%. We had a very good quarter in digital. And then on the institutional business, one area that [we] probably need to give a little more attention to, that is what we call the Professional Information Business. That grew 8%. That's the best growth I can recall in recent memory. And the real driver of it is the Risk and Compliance business. And the Risk and Compliance business is an area that, I think in fiscal '19, revenues exceeded $130 million. When we separated, it may have been $20 million or $30 million. That is a very big focus. And I guess -- I look at the marketplace for Risk and Compliance, I think globally, that's a $60-plus billion market in the next -- over the next couple of years. So it's a huge TAM and one that we are a player in.

And so I think when we stack up versus the New York Times, a, we have a very big institutional presence that they don't and none of our peers do. So it very much differentiates us. When I think about our consumer revenues, again, first quarter, consumer circulation grew 6%. I think that's higher than the New York Times. On digital for us, digital is over 40% of -- digital advertising at Dow Jones is over 40% of total advertising. And importantly, from a profit contribution standpoint, we've been improving our profitability. And so it is -- I think we have a different strategy than New York Times, but I'm very proud of what we're building at Dow Jones.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: And could you maybe -- I guess maybe elaborate on that strategy. The differences in your strategy, so...

MICHAEL FLORIN: Well, I mean I think that, look, from a Times perspective, clearly, and I don't really want to talk too much about Times. Clearly, it's been much of a volume story. I think ours is very balanced. If you look at our pricing structure as an example, our pricing varies from $38.99 to $44.99, very different price point than New York Times. And what it means is that from -- and as you kind of drill down to the financials, our subscriber revenue growth has grown 6%. I think that's probably almost double. They were 3% or 4% in the first quarter. So look, it's a different strategy. Our pricing point is higher. We may be a little bit more of utility to some extent. But I think we have lots of levers to grow growth. And I think we've come a long way.

And just as another example of that is the Wall Street Journal today, 71% of the subscribers, at least as of fiscal first quarter, were digital-only. That's a very big number that I don't think -- I'm not sure there's any peer that has that level of digital exposure. And also, if I look at the whole company, about 65% of Dow Jones revenues are digital today. It is a digital -- it is a very much of a digital company.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: Look, maybe -- Robert Thomson has spoken about, in the past, about the negative impact of the digital duopoly, in other words, Facebook and Google on general digital growth. And I guess in the past year, there's been some positive developments, such as the removal of first free click requirements on Google. You recently announced a partnership with Facebook. And earlier in the year, you also announced the deal with Apple. So how does this change, the game, not just the News Corp but the publishers more generally? And I guess what more could be done?

MICHAEL FLORIN: Right. So I think you're seeing, in at least, the beginnings of a fundamental shift between the relationship between the publishers and big tech, beginning. And I have to say, I give a lot of credit to Rupert, Lachlan and Robert Thomson for getting there. We're not all the way there, but we're making progress.

Look, our goal has been to make sure premium content, our journalism is protected and rewarded. And I think, for too long, big tech has used our content to drive audiences and advertising and there has to be some change. So you are seeing, both from a public perspective, the U.S. regulators globally, the global legislation. I mean you are starting to see a change and also from us. There's clearly been an issue and that's now starting to change.

So as it comes down to working with Facebook, they're clearly starting to see some sense of -- sort of sensibility in terms of subscriptions. They're starting to support it, hopefully, with the news tab feature, being able to work with Facebook. When I look at Facebook, there's a licensing fee, right? Carriage fee, call it. And there's upside in advertising and subscriptions to the extent that someone clicks on the headlines that we're providing, they'll come to -- it will be in our -- they'll go to our platforms. So it's a very important step. I can't say it's all the way there. But from where we were a few years ago, when we talked about the idea of a carriage fee, I had mentioned to investors and it sort of seems like a crazy idea. It happened in the cable industry and the broadcast industry partly because -- and very much because of the old News Corp. And now you're starting to see the beginnings of a carriage fee that we had talked about 2 years ago. So more needs to be done.

I mean if I think about -- I came from advertising. That's where I started my career way back when. And when I was in advertising, you wanted to have lots of media to use. And it wasn't down to 2 platforms when it came to advertising. And so from an advertiser, there clearly is -- the marketplace is very opaque and you want to see changes. And I do think that there is a heck a lot of value in a verified trusted content like ours. And hopefully, we'll start to see changes. But look, I think over the last 12 months, we've seen a big change. And for us, the Facebook deal in and of itself will have an impact on our financials this year. And it's just the beginning, and hopefully, we can layer that in with hopefully other deals. And it is the beginning of a new revenue stream for us.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: This is the one and we are taking questions from the floor. If anyone has any questions? All right, we might move on then. Just I guess where we're on News and Information Services, maybe we'll just do an around the ground throughout the other countries. And maybe starting with the U.K. It looks like things are improving there. Can you maybe talk about the drivers of that improvement? And I guess, how should we think about the evolution of News UK over 3 to 5 years?

MICHAEL FLORIN: It's a good question. So if I think about today, and I look at the first quarter, and I look at things on, obviously, putting aside currency, which has issues with us -- for us. But advertising in the U.K. grew on a local basis, 6%, which is the best in recent periods. So we had very strong growth and very much it was -- print was fairly stable if not improving a little bit and the real growth came from digital. And particularly The Sun was a particular -- had shown particular strength. Audience for The Sun is now globally, 129 million. I think we've overtaken in the U.K., at least the Mail. So we're seeing really good progress. There's still more to be done, but we've seen really good progress. The Times continues to grow subscribers, had a really good clip. And digitally, I think we grew high teens, The Times and digital subscribers. Now over 50% of the subscribers are digital-only. So we made a lot of progress.

And I look at categories, it's all -- it really does vary quarter-over-quarter. Finance and legal happen to be a big category for us. Retail was okay. I think it improved a little bit, but still there are challenges in retail. But you then have seen -- what I really like what I saw in the first quarter was the growth at The Sun. And so very hard to predict and visibility is still fairly limited, but it was a real progress at the U.K. And the biggest challenge for the U.K. was the Tabcorp, the settlement that they had in the prior year. Excluding that, they are really one of the highlights for us in the first quarter.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: Maybe moving to Australia. So you're seeing soft revenue trends in local currency terms. And I guess to what extent is the weakness in advertising revenue, structural versus cyclical versus I guess, maybe a sort of macro-driven? And I guess, how far until we reach that tipping point where digital might outweigh print declines.

MICHAEL FLORIN: Yes. I mean, I think, look, we're not alone in the trends we saw in Australia. I mean Australia, the economy has been has been tough. I mean when GDP is growing 1.4%, and confidence isn't great, you see it. I mean customer -- consumer confidence has a lot to do with it. But look, when I look at Australia, there -- some of it's cyclical, some of it's structural. When you look at the categories, what are the categories that were most vulnerable to? It was employment, it's classified, it's retail, it's real estate, all kind of makes sense. Now how much of that decline is cyclical versus structural, probably a little bit of both.

And for us, the key is to push digital as aggressively as we can. And we've actually done a pretty good job. News.com.au, I think, for 2 years now is the #1 news site in Australia and is doing very well. Our News Xtend, our small, medium business solutions product is doing very well, and it's diversifying that revenue stream.

When I look at -- clearly, a very big focus for us in Australia is on paid subscriptions. And last quarter, we had over $500,000. I think it was 540,000 of our masses were digital subscribers. The Australian, I think, 2/3 of the Australian subscribers are now digital-only. So we've made a very -- real good progress. I think -- when I think about the -- when I think about all of Australia, it's really about -- it's about the metro media, the metro mastheads, The Australian, news.com.au, those are the businesses that clearly have a much bigger digital opportunity than the community and regionals. And while we do this, we have to continue to look at the cost base, any cost that we can, wherever we can streamline costs, whether it's operations, whether it's distribution, whether it's production, you have to take a look at that because it is about making sure you've got the right cost base for the future.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: Yes, that's probably actually a good segue to just talk about cost across the News and Information Services segment more broadly. Maybe if you could just provide an update on the cost reduction programs. I know you've sort of -- you've mentioned sort of the areas of focus in Australia, but also, I guess, other countries as well.

MICHAEL FLORIN: Yes. So I mean I think when I break out the costs, when I think about the segment. So overall, for us, in the first quarter, our costs were down about 4%. And if I break that down, and when we -- where we prioritize, we are investing in Dow Jones, right? And we should be because there are multiple levers of growth. And that one is -- and I think we talked about the expenses at Dow Jones grew less than our revenue growth in the first quarter. So if you think about mid-single-digit -- low to mid-single-digit type revenue expense growth.

When I look at the U.K. and Australia, it is about really kind of focusing on the costs. While you're investing in digital, you've got to look at every cost. So at the U.K., we've seen really good progress on the cost side. It's -- again, it's production, it's distribution, it's marketing where we can. It's really looking at everything to make sure we are balanced.

And I think in Australia, it's the same. I mean we're sharing our content where we can. But we spent a lot of time looking at and making sure that we have the right cost model, and there's more to be done there. And so that clearly is a big focus, but it really is bifurcating that Dow jones you invest in and the others. You certainly invest in digital, but you've got to make sure your print costs are as low as possible.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: Just before we move on. I guess talk about some of the other businesses. Are there any questions from the floor on news and info services? We've got one at the front here.

HAROLD VOGEL;VOGEL CAPITAL INC.;ANALYST: Customer acquisition cost, what is the trend on that? And also, I assume newsprint cost is going down because you're using [it] as payment. Can you comment on that? And what proportion of that is [overflown]?

MICHAEL FLORIN: So -- by way Hal Vogel was a professor mine at Columbia Business School, about 20-some-odd years now. So a very good question. He always asks good questions.

Look, on the SAC, we don't get into. I would say that when we look at SAC, how you -- the subscribers we're adding are very nicely accretive. They are NPV positive. So when you think about like the newsroom, we think about the journal in particular, you do -- hopefully, we'll do a little bit more in social media, but they are positive.

Now you keep an eye on churn. Churn in digital is higher than in print because print, we tend to have much more longer-tenured subscribers. As it relates to your other question, newsprint is fairly small. Newsprint prices have started to come down. And you're right, there's both -- there's a variable component of it. As volume comes down, newsprint also comes down. But also, we start to see the newsprint prices starting to come down as well. But they're not -- as a percentage, newsprint is -- wouldn't be that significant as a percentage.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: Are there any other questions from the floor? Okay, we might move on. Maybe we'll move on to digital real estate services. I think maybe we'll start with Australia. I guess REA's sort of have been a very highly successful business and arguably the jewel in the crown. Can you just talk about the strategy to continue to grow REA in Australia, just given it's already the clear #1 player?

And just in particular, touch on their new lead-based products, maybe if you've got any initial feedback from takeup from agents. And also, I guess, longer term, how could REA potentially monetize leads?

MICHAEL FLORIN: Yes. It's a great question because you're right. We're #1 in the market. And you always get -- how do you continue to grow? And when I look at REA, clearly, listings are a factor. But the kind of -- the growth that -- the growth drivers are really about how you continue to push debt penetration, and I think there are plenty of opportunities for us to do so. It's looking at a number of products. I mean we've got whether it's Agent Elevate, Agent Match, which is the selling -- which is in its early days was audience maximizer whether it's adding in lifestyle content -- there's a lot that, from a product standpoint, that we have continued to do. And many of those front page, another example. Many of them are in the very early days. So it is about kind of debt penetration and learning on new products.

Then it's also about using data. I mean the Hometrack acquisition was great because we have access to all this property that we had not before. And so what we're doing is we're building a really powerful database that we didn't have before. And how do you leverage that to drive both the industry and customer adoption?

Then I look at the mortgage brokering business. I mean that is in the early, early days. And that's another way of leveraging leads. And how do you better monetize leads? And so -- then outside of Australia, you've got -- you have exposure to Southeast Asia through iProperty, which is also in the early days. So I think REA has lots of levers to grow.

Now you mentioned the sell lead, Agent Match. It's in the really early days. I mean we're in the days of learning and testing and learning. But it's clearly a big -- hopefully, a very big opportunity for REA. It's just -- it's very early at this point. But it's another way of thinking about the business and how do you better monetize leads going forward. And right now, we're sort of building a pipeline of leads and really getting reviews from the industry.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: Yes. And I think -- is it worth just maybe highlighting, for the audience here, just to what extent the soft Australian listings environment has been a drag on revenue and sort of what revenue -- sort of revenue and say, a per listing basis, has sort of done, if you sort of -- if you took out these macro drags?

MICHAEL FLORIN: Well, it's always tough to predict out the macro drags. I mean, for us, listings aren't clearly a lever of growth. And look, in the last 2 quarters in particular, it's been unusual. First quarter, we had, I think, 15% listing volume declines. And I think revenues were down $8 million. Now part of that, there was an increase in deferral revenues from going related to the Premier All product. But still, I mean, it is a factor. Now -- and it also depends on geography, right? So if the 2 biggest markets, the highest yielding markets are Melbourne and Sydney. If those are down, then they also have an impact.

So look, the last 2 quarters have been unusual. We're starting to see, at least, and we talked about sort of gradual improvements. We have seen Melbourne and Sydney, at least based on sort of the industry data that we see, is starting to get less bad. We're also managing the cost base. So when we do see recovery, I think we'll be in a pretty good place. And so I think second half comps, as a former analyst, I can look at it and say we had second half comps, I think industry listing volumes were down, I think, 9% in the third quarter, and I think fourth quarter, it will be down 19%. So we're -- very unusual territory. And again, managing the cost base is the right thing to do.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: Maybe we'll just move on to the U.S. now, in digital real estate services. So you made your biggest acquisition move 5 years ago, yes? Can you provide an update on how this business is performing? Maybe talk about how that it moves differentiating versus CLO and also how the Opcity acquisition fits in.

MICHAEL FLORIN: Yes. So look, I mean, I think when we acquired REALTOR, we always -- I always get questions from investors, how do we differentiate? And what are we doing to differentiate from Zillow? Obviously, we have relationship with the NAR. Our listings were updated more frequently. And so we're differing -- and we had different types of products. But clearly, Zillow seems to be very -- getting much more aggressive in the home segment and the house flipping segment. It's not an area that we're particularly interested in. It's much more capital-intensive and not the pipe business that we are focused on.

For us, it really is the biggest part of our revenue is the buy side. And today, it's through connection plus product, where we were essentially subscriptions -- we sell subscriptions to the industry by ZIP Code. They could be exclusive or nonexclusive. That's been the biggest part of the business. They've been unqualified, we just sell leads. Now the next phase is really exciting. It's the Opcity. So Opcity, what it does is Opcity is based on -- it's a performance-based model. And we will qualify the lead and then connect, in almost real time, with the agent that's most likely to convert. And there are algorithms and there's learning built into to Opcity. And so that's the next phase where we're moving from a marketplace of -- there's a wide range of estimates of what the real estate marketplace is, whether it's $8 billion to $10 billion. There's a wide range to one that is going after the $60 billion to $80 billion commission pool through a performance-based model. So working with the industry, we're hopefully making it easier for them to as we provide leads that are more likely to convert. And that's a very big focus of realtor now is moving from just the unqualified lead to one that is really performance-based. And I think it's very exciting.

What we've been doing is testing Opcity in over a dozen markets, testing what would be -- in most markets, we offer the Connection Plus, the unqualified lead product, the lead gen product and the Opcity product. In most markets, we offer both, and over a dozen markets, we're offering just Opcity. And seeing how that goes. So far, it's early, but the tests are very favorable. And we're seeing an uptick in meeting rates, uptick in conversions, uptick in home values. So, so far, so good. It's early days, but one that we're watching very, very closely.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: Maybe more sort of broadly speaking on the Digital Real Estate Services segment. Robert's spoken about his ambition for News Corp to become a global player. So could you maybe talk about your strategy across the sort of -- the more global portfolio of assets?

MICHAEL FLORIN: Right. It's a great question. So -- and when I think about the frame, for those that don't follow News Corp too closely, to frame it, Digital Real Estate generated almost $1.2 billion of revenues last year and almost $400 million of EBITDA. So this is, I think, by most metrics, we're the largest in the world. And we recently moved Tracey Fellows, who was the CEO of REA Group, to be the President of our Global Digital Real Estate. And also, she is the interim CEO of REALTOR. So clearly, that in of itself shows the commitment that we have by bringing someone like Tracey to oversee the -- our digital real estate portfolio.

And when I think about it, we have global scale that most don't have. We have the ability, through this network, to see what verticals perform well. To see where you want to access or allocate capital. There are certain markets that you can test things and certain markets that may have been more favorable than others. But it gives you a learning that you'd -- that most companies don't have. And so from an IP perspective, there may be some opportunities, from a shared learning perspective, there are opportunities. And when I step back and I look and see, REA is probably the most profitable digital real estate company in the world, my guess. And to be able to import some of that learning to a realtor, I think, is really important. So the more that we can share best practices, I think the better off we are.

And we have exposure, not just through -- if you think about it, it's Australia, it's the U.S., it's the Southeast Asia through iProperty, we have a minority stake in India through [Elara]. So we really do have a global presence. And to have someone now accountable for the whole segment and where we want, as a company, to allocate capital, I think, is very important.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: Cool. May I just take this opportunity to check if there's any questions from the floor on digital real estate before we move on to some of the other segments? Okay. Cool. Maybe we might move on to Foxtel. Maybe just -- if we start with, maybe can you provide an update on your new IP products? Obviously, an update on Kayo Sports, which was launched about a year ago now? And also the new entertainment app. And maybe we can just -- if we could talk about how the economics stack up versus Foxtel's cable.

MICHAEL FLORIN: Right. What a great question, and clearly, a very big focus for Foxtel is pushing OTT or IP, in part because -- and when the contribution margins and the margin of the product were leveraging the cost that we already have and amortizing over a bigger base.

And so -- and think about what we're trying to do, Kayo, which is our sports streaming service, which we launched at the end of November a year ago. I mean I only give -- as the first quarter -- oh, I guess that's in November 5, we had over 400,000 -- I think it was 402,000 paying subscribers. I think it was over 440,000 including trialists. So that's a pretty good -- in less than a year, to have scaled it at over 400,000. And these are not $6.99, $7.99 subscribers, and the retail rate for Kayo starts at $25. So you really are at the higher end. And I think we've done a really good job. And so it's early days still, and we'll see kind of what the ultimate TAM is and how much market share we can go after.

But the reality is, I think they've done a really good job. I mean to have 400,000 on a base of, we have over 3 million -- 3.1 million total subscribers, including IP, that's starting to really scale and that's what we want to see. And it's still early days, but a very big focus for us.

As it relates to the entertainment, we have Foxtel Now, which I view as more of a mirror of broadcast to some extent, more of a complement to broadcast. The -- what we have talked about, we haven't given the specifics yet, is an entertainment product, which we expect to launch sometime in the fiscal year. But again, it's going to leverage the content we already have. And so that clearly is a very big focus for Foxtel. And it is the core -- the growth engine of Foxtel. There's lots that you can do from a cost side. There's opportunities on churn, but really kind of pushing OTT is sort of what I view as the single biggest growth driver for Foxtel.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: You mentioned cost there a couple of times. And obviously, it is a key focus. So I guess there's a lot of moving parts in FY '20. So maybe if you could -- could you touch on that? And also, more broadly, how should we think about the cost of sports rights going forward? You've obviously locked in and have some key content for the next few years.

MICHAEL FLORIN: So I think if I think about all Foxtel, the cost, the biggest cost for fiscal '20, there are 2 items that really are the driver of it. One is, and we've talked about this on our earnings call, there is some noncash amortization related to how we amortize feature programming -- some of the feature programming. It's -- again, it's noncash. That's $30 million to $35 million. We have one additional quarter of domestic Cricket. Recall, we had bought the domestic Cricket rights a year ago, which we had in the first quarter. So now going forward, it should be like for like with some very modest escalators.

If I think about Foxtel, because there's a lot of other stuff we're doing. The overhead costs have started to come down. There are opportunities on the transmission side, which we can talk about. But overall, it's really that the noncash costs are probably the biggest factor. Outside of that, costs would be relatively stable. So it's mostly driven by that, right? All the puts and takes, that's probably the biggest factor from a cost standpoint.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: I want just to check with the floor if there are any questions on Foxtel, before we move on to -- I want to touch on a couple of other segments and I know we're running out of time. Cool.

Maybe if we just may move on to Book Publishing quickly. That business has held up remarkably given the potential headwinds this business faces. So why do you think this is the case? And should we be thinking of this as a publishing business or as a content business?

MICHAEL FLORIN: So the latter part of your question to me, that's the way I think about it. And what I mentioned earlier is when I think of Harper, it's clearly a book business, but at the same time, it really is about the content. I mean we have a library of over 300,000 titles across, I think, 17 different languages. And so it really is about IP.

And one of the things that we're looking at is -- and thinking about it, how do we expand beyond that, right? Beyond just the core business? Audio book is [a] business that emerged out of nowhere a couple of years ago to be a real big contributor for us, for -- on digital revenues perspective. Now how do we think about outside of just the book business? And so we have a deal with Sony we're working on where we will participate in an upside from literary work through the former Fox 2000 team. I think it was Elizabeth Gabler.

And we also have a deal with Bell Media to monetize some of the Harlequin titles and these made for TV films. And so thinking about that more holistically, I think, is really important because it really is about IP. I mean we own the content in perpetuity in many cases. And so how do we better leverage that beyond just the audio or e-book or physical book? So we're very -- it is a business that we're very excited by.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: Yes. And I guess how -- broadly, more broadly speaking, how would you think about the evolution of this business over the next 3 to 5 years? And I know, even strategically, like you've done a deal in the past in China, albeit not that big but could you maybe elaborate a bit on that?

MICHAEL FLORIN: Well, I think, look, any quarter -- like year-to-year, it can vary. Like this year we talked about, we do face tough compares this year, and we have a number of titles that are much more second half weighted. We keep an eye on retail because that's something that also can change over time. Barnes & Noble has a new owner that we keep an eye on. But when I think about -- it is about making sure that you have the right mix of titles. And I think about the fiscal last year, it was really about -- it was very much about having the right titles. And if you have the right titles, you can have significant operating leverage.

And look, it will be tough over the next couple of years. I think sort of the nonbook business will become a bigger part of the business. It'll be interesting to see digital revenues for us today. I think last quarter, they were 22%. Where can that go longer term? Particularly as you think about this explosion of content, whether it's streaming, whether it's podcast. I mean these are all opportunities, whether it's subscription-based models. These are all opportunities that HarperCollins theoretically could be participating in. So I do think of it very much of a content business.

And when I think about the right compare, I mean the nice thing about Harper is like in any given quarter, you could have half of your revenues already accounted for through the backlist. So -- and it's a business that does not require a lot of CapEx and one that I think has plenty of long-term potential.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: I might just check to see if there's any questions on Book Publishing? Maybe one final one for me. Just a more general question, just around capital management. You've got $1.7 billion net -- of cash sitting on your balance sheet outside of the borrowings relating to Foxtel and potentially more if you do end up selling assets. So how are you looking to deploy this?

MICHAEL FLORIN: Right, so that's a question that we certainly get a lot. And for us, I mean we are a company that is going through, as I mentioned, at the starting point, we're a company that is going through change. And if I think about the investments we made, I mean the biggest investments have been in real estate and book publishing, either Harlequin or REALTOR or even REA through the iProperty acquisition.

So I do think, for us, reinvestment is very important. We're trying to shift the narrative of the company to one that is much more of a digital-first company. But at the same time, I think look, we should look at all levers. I mean, I think at the end of the day, I mean, we have a very good sense of what our value is. We know very clear where the disconnects are. And I know Robert's talked a lot about sort of some of the parts and how do we best narrow that gap. Not only narrow the gap but grow the NAV. And so in the past, it really has been about reinvestment and are there opportunities that can do both, that close and grow. That's the way I think about it.

THOMAS G. BEADLE: Okay. Great. Are there any final questions from the floor? Okay. Looks like that's it. Mike, thank you very much for coming in. And all the best.

MICHAEL FLORIN: Great. My pleasure. Thanks for having me.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XR0-D1X1-JBJ7-N53B-00000-00News Corp calls for 'firmer action' but media sector swings behind tech reforms2019-12-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:00ZLexisNexisNews Corp calls for 'firmer action' but media sector swings behind tech reformsJennifer Duke and Fergus Hunter

News Corp Australasia executive chairman Michael Miller has criticised the government's plans to regulate Facebook and Google

News Corp Australasia executive chairman Michael Miller has criticised the Morrison government's decision to allow Facebook and Google to face voluntary rules as "out-of-kilter" and has pushed for a stronger response to regulating the tech titans.

But the Rupert Murdoch controlled media giant, which has led the charge to regulate big tech companies in recent years, was not supported by other Australian media organisations which broadly welcomed the news.

The Morrison government confirmed on Thursday it would accept the majority of the competition regulator's recommendations in its crackdown on the digital services, including a pilot program for an ombudsman, a review of media regulations, improved digital literacy and sweeping privacy changes.

Mr Miller said he believed more should be done to protect traditional news providers.

"Most of these initial steps are aligned with where the world is heading but more reforms are needed to protect consumers and ensure a vibrant and viable media industry," he said in a statement.

"However, the Government's approach of a voluntary code of conduct to oversee commercial arrangements as a first step appears out-of-kilter with leaders of other jurisdictions who have advocated firmer action."

Nine Entertainment Co chief executive Hugh Marks expressed "strong support" for the government's response and was supportive of a voluntary code. Nine is the owner of this masthead.

"I'm very pleased the government has strongly endorsed adopting those regulations," he said. "It's obviously better if we can work it out directly with the platforms ... A voluntary code is the right way to go."

While the "devil is in the detail" when it comes to changing media regulation, Mr Marks threw his support behind changes that would level the playing field.

"The general thing for me is the government's tone and their obvious commitment to making this happen is to be congratulated and I'm really pleased that they've got on the front foot," he said.

Seven West Media chief executive James Warburton also welcomed the majority of the response, saying in a statement that addressing outdated content requirements would bring certainty to the industry.

"The urgent need for regulatory equality between foreign digital platforms and Australian companies has been recognised by the Government. We see this as a real turning point, as for too long legislation has lagged well behind technological evolution, disadvantaging Australian companies and providing foreign digital platforms with a free ride," he said.

However, he said the network was disappointed that the government had not backed a take-down scheme that would've required material infringing copyright rules to face more stringent requirements. The suggestion attracted mixed feedback from submissions throughout the consultation process.

Network Ten chief executive Paul Anderson said it was "great the government is making a serious attempt to address the deep-rooted dominance of the online tech and streaming giants".

The tech giants have not yet shared in detail their stance on the government's position.

Facebook director of policy for Australia and New Zealand Mia Garlick said the social media site shared the view "that now is an opportune time for democratic countries like Australia to work with industry on new regulation for the internet that protects the choice and opportunities for millions of Australians that use our services".

A Google spokeswoman said the search giant had worked closely with the authorities "and will continue to do so in 2020".
